title: Who has the luck...
content:
...to play the Keen 4,5,6 games in original MS-DOS, with all hardware working?

I am, my 2100Mhz Pentium 4 runs on Windows 98, and my sound card still even has Adlib support! Any other lucky fellows who don't need DOSbox? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] ____________
I have a boring signature.

...
Ah, [url=http://DaVince.sitesled.com/]site[/url].

title: Re: Who has the luck...
content:
[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img] I wish.. Or well, I have my Keen-O-Matic (my previous computer), but I haven't used it for a while because it makes some strange noise and I'm afraid it'll burn the house. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] I should somehow get a pure Keen-O-Matic to this room..

And, you're lucky! Keen 1-3 works fine with PC speaker sounds on this comp, but the movement in others isn't normal without the aid of DosBox.. Not to mention I can't hear the cool sounds without DosBox..

I think I'll play some Keen now.. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] 3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: Ich hasst dur ... umm, luck.
content:
I've got a hundred of those things. [url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/sq/]Literally[/url]. I wish it was easier to give some of them to other Keeners.

One lucky machine takes pride of place in my lounge.

200MHz
32Mb RAM
3Gb HDD (I think)
PSone style four-button Gravis gamepad
20" CRT monitor

It's attached to a four-way KVM switch, which allows me to flip between the MP3 machine [also a 200MHz, running a highly tweaked Win98SE], the DOS Beast and whatever other machines I need to use, without messing around with cords.

Plus, as it's on the same setup as my MP3 machine, it's also connected to my stereo (which also can switch between the two puters), cranking through four 10" speakers.

DOS + BASS = [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-christmas.gif[/img]

It boots in 5 seconds, is capable of filesharing across a Microsoft workgroup, and runs ANYTHING. No clearing TSRs for me. Check the MEM output below. The one problem at the moment is that the software to access the workgroup doesn't like running alongside an LSL IPX layer used for network gaming, so I need to dual boot for that sort of thing.

Been meaning to document this thing for a while--I'll post a few pictures and the AUTOEXEC and CONFIG for anyone serious about DOS gaming.

[pre] Modules using memory below 1 MB: Name Total Conventional Upper Memory -------- ---------------- ---------------- ---------------- SYSTEM 13,104 (13K) 13,056 (13K) 48 (0K) COMMAND 3,280 (3K) 3,008 (3K) 272 (0K) BASIC 13,696 (13K) 13,696 (13K) 0 (0K) FDXMS 1,808 (2K) 0 (0K) 1,808 (2K) IFSHLP 3,968 (4K) 0 (0K) 3,968 (4K) PROTMAN 400 (0K) 0 (0K) 400 (0K) RTSND 41,376 (40K) 0 (0K) 41,376 (40K) NDISHLP 1,440 (1K) 0 (0K) 1,440 (1K) NWLINK 10,144 (10K) 0 (0K) 10,144 (10K) PROTMAN 2,560 (3K) 0 (0K) 2,560 (3K) Free 725,280 (708K) 623,424 (609K) 101,856 (99K)Memory Type Total Used Free---------------- -------- -------- --------Conventional 638K 29K 609KUpper 160K 61K 99KReserved 226K 226K 0KExtended (XMS) 47,104K 15,527K 31,577K---------------- -------- -------- --------Total memory 48,128K 15,843K 32,285KTotal under 1 MB 798K 90K 708KLargest executable program size 609K (623,360 bytes)Largest free upper memory block 99K (101,616 bytes)FreeDOS is resident in the high memory area.[/pre]

title: Ich habe viel Gluck! Ja, sehr gern!
content:
I use the "craptop." It's an old Toshiba laptop from like 1993. 800x600 resolution.

Pentium like... 90 or 60 megahertz. I am not quite sure which it is. It can run DOS games in 98 without any problems. AND it can pay Tyrian with the "FM" sound selected.

The way it is supposed to be heard.

Ahem yes... I should upload some pictures sometime. It's pretty funny. All ripped apart and banged up. And the cool thing is I can run MSN messenger on it. XD I have it sitting next to my bed so I can play keen or whatever I want to late at night.

Which I hardly ever do because I usually am sleeping.-----------------------
The end of this post. You may stop reading now.

title: Re: Ich habe viel Gluck! Ja, sehr gern!
content:
I wish I had such a sound system.. I hope I one day hear Spleen's Dos bass.. It's so annoying I was so near hearing them, only few hundred kilometres away from him, in Melbourne. But unfortunately I had almost no money left as I was robbed in Sydney earlier that.. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-rolleyes.gif[/img]
[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img]

Yeah, sounds pretty excellent, that Dos machine. Yeah, it's good idea to document all that stuff, as you now have a new site and all.. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img] 3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: KEEN!!!
content:
I have my retrocomputer which currently runs Windows 98, although I'll probably set it up to run pure DOS eventually as well.
I just don't feel like going through the trouble right now.
It's a HP Vectra VEi7 C566, with a 566 MHz Celeron, although I plan on replacing it with a 633 I think it is, which I have lying around, but again, too much trouble right now. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
I have an original Gravis PC GamePad with it, the very object that introduced me to Commander Keen (1), or truthfully my second one, since my first has a repaired-rabbit-chewed-cord, making it slightly less cool.

The soundcard is buggy though, MIDI sounds OK, but some wave stuff sounds completely wrong.
It's OK in Keen, but when I tried Goblins 3 (Goblins Quest) for instance, the voices were just clicking and garbled noise.
Doom on the other hand plays OK, so I'm not sure what the problem is.
Getting off-topic here.

A friend of mine left me another computer, which should be a bit faster, which is nice for what I want with it.
Problem is he left it in the garage for quite a while, so the thing needs cleaning first.Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

Also funny how I can hear FM sound in most MS-DOS games (yes, Tyrian too!) even through my surround set, but I can't get the gamepad to work... Ah well.

Lol, 086s and 286s are a bit TOO far back... We had a 286 once. It was all yellow with a 4-colour monitor (yellow, darker yellow, brown, black), 640kb RAM, and an I dunno how big harddisk (I think around 64 MB? I dunno for sure.)____________
I have a boring signature.

title: Re: KEEN!!!
content:
I really don't mind using DOSbox (when it works). I'd rather Keen on the same Linux box I use for everything else. Demanding games like Tyrian and Privateer II are a little disappointing though. I do miss actual PC speaker sounds. Emulators just don't have the same charm. My desktop has a real PC speaker, but I don't suppose DOSbox can send anything to it.

Spleen's sound system truly sounds like a wonder. I remember sitting in front of a DOS machine in a pitch-black room, just me and Privateer coming through what was (at the time) a huge monitor and my almighty 2.1 speaker system. Yet it pales in comparison to his setup.

I wish there were some way I could hook up my Gravis gamepad to my laptop. I went to all the trouble of opening it up and rewiring it to make it work again, and now I have no place to plug it in. I'd kill for a USB version, but there's no way I'm going to hack my only one. If I had a backup I'd hack it in a second.________________
[img]http://img80.imageshack.us/img80/8498/missouriansf9.png[/img]

Wait wait wait, Spleen... how the devil do you have 798K free? You got some tweaked version of DOS running, too? I thought 640k base was all that was allowed? That's fantastic; the wiring to have a dedicated mp3 machine sounds awesome. The closest I have to that is an input on the entertainment speaker system in my livingroom that lets me hook up my iPod/laptop/whatever.

What do the tweaks on your Win98SE do? I finally upgraded my shoddy little laptop (433mhz, used to have 32MB RAM, now has 256, and used to have 4gb HD, now has 30gb)... and I'd love to tweak/customize my setup.

[hr]Xky Wait wait wait, Spleen... how the devil do you have 798K free? You got some tweaked version of DOS running, too?
[hr]I'm using FreeDOS 9, which takes up far less conventional memory than DOS 6.22 (about 18K when loaded high). In addition, I use [url=http://sorry.vse.cz/~roman/dimension/rdos/rdosumb/]RDOSUMB[/url], which swipes unused cache from the BIOS to be used as extra UMB space. It requires some experimentation to get it working right, but it's worth it.

[hr][fdconfig.sys]
file=8
fcbs=1,0
device=c:\dos\driver dosumb dosumb.com * #1D
dos=high,umb
devicehigh=c:\dos\driver dxms.sys
devicehigh=c: et\ifshlp.sys
devicehigh=c:\dos\driver dosumb\upload.com /e

[autoexec.bat]

c:\dos\driver dosumb\upload.com /d
lh c: et et initialize
lh c: et wlink
lh c: et et start
[hr]

Without installing the network, I have abot 620k free conventional memory. The 700+ figure includes upper memory.

As for Win98, you should look into [url=http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?s=c92dd2348a007c3c7cbdd8794dd28e8a&showforum=91]this forum[/url].

Definitely get Win98SE Unofficial Service Pack (ooh, new version--must grab that). Revolutions Pack is a good idea in theory, but I've only tried the previous version last year which screwed a few things up. I think those problems have been fixed now, though.

98Lite is nice too, though not listed at that forum. It goes through and makes a whole bunch of components optional, listing them in Add/Remove. It's shareware, though, but I don't remember the limitations.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-pirate.gif[/img]

Search up the following updates, too.

4756US8 (Fixes those stupid hangs at shutdown)
240075up, 241134usa8 (ME transplant for USB support)
98NativeUSB22e (Allows support for most USB storage, etc)
MeSCANFRAG (ME's faster scandisk and defrag)

There's all sorts of fun stuff if you search around a bit for Win98 tweaks. I'll be starting a section at my site dedicated to this stuff soon, but that should be enough info for now.
